

Let us summarize our findings about curvature and torsion.


::: Important
### Summary

Recall that:

1. Curvature $\kappa$ is defined only for regular curves.
2. Torsion $\tau$ is defined only for regular curves with non-vanishing $\kappa$.
3. Both $\kappa$ and $\tau$ are invariant under unit-speed reparametrizations

The two strategies for computing $\kappa$ and $\tau$ are summarized in the diagram in @fig-diagram.

:::

![How to compute $\kappa$ and $\tau$ for regular curve $\g$.](/images/diagram_curvature_torsion.png){#fig-diagram width=80%}




We have already made an example in which we compute
curvature and torsion of the Helix using the general formulas
$$
\kappa = \frac{\norm{ \dg \times \ddg }}{ \norm{ \dg }^2 } \,, \qquad
\tau = \frac{ (\dg \times \ddg ) \cdot \dddg }{ \norm{ \dg \times \ddg }^2 } \,.
$$
We conclude the section by providing an example where we compute curvature and torsion by making use of the Frenet frame.



::: Example
### Curvature and torsion of Helix with Frenet frame

Consider the helix of radius $R>0$ and rise $H$ given by
$$
\g (t) = ( R\cos(t), R\sin(t),t H )\,,
$$
for $t \in \R$. We want to compute curvature and torsion by following the diagram at @fig-diagram.
We ask the first question:
$$
\mbox{Is $\g$ unit-speed?}
$$
We have already computed in Example \ref{example-helix-frenet} that
$$
\norm{ \dg } = \rho \,, \qquad \rho := \sqrt{R^2 + H^2} \,.
$$
This shows that $\g$ is regular but not unit-speed. We ask the second question in the diagram:
$$
\mbox{Can we find the arc-length reparametrization of $\g$?}
$$
We have already computed the arc-length reparametrization
of $\g$ in Example \ref{example-helix-frenet}. This is given
by 
$$
\tg(s) = \left( R \cos \left( \frac{s}{\rho}  \right) ,R \sin \left( \frac{s}{\rho}  \right) , \frac{H s }{\rho}    \right) \,.
$$
The next step in the diagram is
$$
\mbox{Compute Frenet frame $\{ \ttt, \nn, \bb \}$ and curvature $\kappa$, torsion $\tau$}
$$
From Example \ref{example-helix-frenet}, the Frenet frame and curvature of $\tg$ are
\begin{align*}
\tttt & =  \frac{1}{\rho}
 \left(  - R \sin \left( \frac{s}{\rho}  \right) , 
 R \cos \left( \frac{s}{\rho}  \right) 
 , H    \right)\\
\tnn & = \left(  -\cos \left( \frac{s}{\rho}  \right) , -\sin \left( \frac{s}{\rho}  \right) , 0    \right) \\
\tbb & = \frac{1}{\rho} \left(  H\sin \left( \frac{s}{\rho}  \right) , - H \cos \left( \frac{s}{\rho}  \right) ,  R \right) \\
\tkappa & = \norm{ \dot{\tttt} } = \frac{R}{\rho^2} = \frac{R}{R^2 + H^2}
\end{align*}
we are left to compute the torsion using formula
$$
\ttau = - \dot{\tbb} \cdot \tnn 
$$
Indeed, we have
$$
\dot{\tbb} = \frac{H}{\rho^2} \left(  \cos \left( \frac{s}{\rho}  \right) , \sin \left( \frac{s}{\rho}  \right) , 0   \right)
$$
and therefore 
$$
\dot{\tbb} \cdot \nn = \frac{H}{\rho^2} \left( - \cos^2 \left( \frac{s}{\rho}  \right) -  \sin^2 \left( \frac{s}{\rho}  \right) \right) = - \frac{H}{\rho^2} \,.
$$
The torsion is then
$$
\ttau = - \dot{\tbb} \cdot \tnn = \frac{H}{\rho^2} = \frac{H}{R^2 + H^2} \,,
$$
which of course agrees with the calculation for $\tau$ in Example \ref{example-torsion-helix}.

:::




## Frenet-Serret equations

For unit-speed curves $\g \colon (a,b) \to \R^3$ with non-vanishing curvature we introduced the Frenet frame
$$
\{ \ttt, \nn, \bb \} \,.
$$
We proved that the Frenet frame is a positive orthonormal basis of $\R^3$. We also used such basis to compute curvature $\kappa$ and torsion $\tau$ of $\g$:
$$
\kappa := \| \dot{\ttt} \| \,, \quad \tau := - \dot{\bb} \cdot \nn \,. 
$$

In this section we show that the Frenet frame satisfies a linear system of ODEs
known as the Frenet-Serret equations. In order to do this, we first need 
prove that the Frenet frame 
$$
( \ttt, \nn, \bb  )
$$ 
is *right-handed*. Such property holds in 
general for any positive basis of $\R^3$ of the form
$$
(\uu, \vv , \ww ) \,, \qquad \ww := \uu \times \vv \,.
$$



::: Proposition
### Frenet frame is right-handed {#proposition-positive-basis}

Let $\g \colon (a,b) \to \R^3$ be a unit-speed curve with $\kappa \neq 0$. The Frenet frame is *right-handed*, in the sense that
$$
\bb = \ttt \times \nn \,, \quad
\nn = \bb \times \ttt \,, \quad
\ttt = \nn \times \bb \,.
$$ {#eq-frenet-positive-basis}

:::


::: Proof

The first equation in (@eq-frenet-positive-basis) is true by definition of $\bb$. For the remaining $2$ equations, recall formula (@eq-cross-prod-triple): 
$$
(\uu \times \vv ) \times \ww = ( \uu \cdot \ww) \vv - ( \vv \cdot \ww ) \uu \,,
$${#eq-cross-prod-triple-1}
which holds for all $\uu,\vv,\ww \in \R^3$. Applying (@eq-cross-prod-triple-1) to
$$
\uu = \ttt \,, \quad \vv = \nn \,, \quad \ww = \ttt \,,
$$
yields
\begin{align*}
( \ttt \times \nn ) \times \ttt & = ( \ttt \cdot \ttt ) \nn - (\nn \cdot \ttt) \ttt \\
                                      & = \norm{\ttt }^2 \nn - \zero \\
                                      & = \nn \,,
\end{align*}
where we used that $\ttt$ is a unit vector and $\nn \cdot \ttt = 0$. Therefore, by definition of $\bb$, we have
$$
\bb \times \ttt = ( \ttt \times \nn ) \times \ttt = \nn
$$
obtaining the second equation in (@eq-frenet-positive-basis). Now we apply (@eq-cross-prod-triple-1) to 
$$
\uu = \ttt \,, \quad \vv = \nn \,, \quad \ww = \nn \,,
$$
to get
\begin{align*}
( \ttt \times \nn ) \times \nn  & = ( \ttt \cdot \nn ) \nn - (\nn \cdot \nn ) \ttt \\
                                      & = \zero - \| \nn \|^2 \ttt  \\
                                      & = - \ttt
\end{align*}
where we used that $\nn$ is a unit vector and $\ttt \cdot \nn= 0$. Therefore, by definition of $\bb$ and anti-commutativity of the vector product, we have
$$
\nn \times \bb = - \bb \times \nn = - (\ttt \times \nn ) \times \nn = \ttt \,,
$$
obtaining the last equation in (@eq-frenet-positive-basis).
:::





::: Theorem
### Frenet-Serret equations

Let $\g \colon (a,b) \to \R^3$ be unit-speed with $\kappa \neq 0$. The **Frenet-Serret** equations are
\begin{align*}  
\dot{\ttt} & = \kappa \nn \\
\dot{\nn} & = - \kappa \ttt + \tau \bb \\
\dot{\bb} & = -\tau \nn
\end{align*}
:::

::: Proof 

The first Frenet-Serret equation
$$
\dot{\ttt}  = \kappa \nn
$${#eq-proof-frenet-2}
is just the definition of $\nn$. The third Frenet-Serret equation
$$
\dot{\bb} = - \tau \nn
$${#eq-proof-frenet-3}
holds by Proposition \ref{proposition-binormal}. Now, recall that in Proposition \ref{proposition-positive-basis} we have proven
$$
\bb = \ttt \times \nn \,, \quad
\nn = \bb \times \ttt \,, \quad
\ttt = \nn \times \bb \,.
$${#eq-proof-frenet-1}
Differentiating the second equation in (@eq-proof-frenet-1) and using (@eq-proof-frenet-2)-(@eq-proof-frenet-3) we get
\begin{align*}
\dot{\nn} & = \dot{\bb} \times \ttt + \bb \times \dot{\ttt} & \\
          & = ( - \tau \nn \times \ttt) + \bb \times \kappa \nn \\
          & = \tau ( \ttt \times \nn ) - \kappa (\nn \times \bb ) \\
          & = \tau \bb - \kappa \ttt \,,
\end{align*}
where in the last equality we used the first and third equations in
(@eq-proof-frenet-1). The above is exactly the second Frenet-Serret equation.

:::


::: Remark
### Vectorial form of Frenet-Serret equations {#remark-vector-frenet}

We can write the Frenet-Serret ODE sysyem in vectorial form. Introduce the vector
of the Frenet frame
$$
\G = (\ttt, \nn, \bb)
$$
This way $\G$ is a $9$ dimensional time-dependent vector
$$
\G \colon (a,b) \to \R^9
$$
Also define the block matrix
$$
\mathbf{A} =
\left(
\begin{array}{ccc}
\zero & \kappa I & \zero \\
- \kappa I & \zero & \tau I  \\
\zero & -\tau I & \zero 
\end{array}
\right) \,,
$$
where we denoted
$$
\zero :=
\left(
\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0  \\
0 & 0 & 0
\end{array}
\right) \,, \quad 
I := \left(
\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & 0  \\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{array}
\right) \,.
$$
This way $\mathbf{A}$ is a $9 \times 9$ time-dependent matrix
$$
\mathbf{A} \colon (a,b) \to \R^{9 \times 9}
$$
It is immediate to check that the Frenet-Serret equations can be written as
$$
\dot{\G} = \mathbf{A} \G
$$


**Note:** The matrix $\mathbf{A}$ is anti-symmetric, that is
$$
\mathbf{A}^T = - \mathbf{A} \,.
$$
This observation will be crucial in proving the *Fundamental Theorem of Space Curves*, which is stated in the next section.


**Alternative Notation:** With a little abuse of notation we can also write the 
Frenet-Serret equations as
$$
\dot{\G} = A \G
$$
where $A$ is the $3 \times 3$ time-dependent matrix 
$$
A \colon (a,b) \to \R^{3 \times 3} \,, \quad A := \left(
\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & \kappa  & 0 \\
- \kappa  & 0 & \tau  \\
0 & -\tau  & 0
\end{array}
\right)  \,,
$$
and where we think $\G$ as a 3 dimensional vector, with each component being a function $\ttt, \nn$ and $\bb$.

Note that the block in poisition $(i,j)$ of $\mathbf{A}$ is obtained by multiplying
by $I$ the entry $(i,j)$ of $A$.

:::




## Fundamental Theorem of Space Curves

The most important consequence of the Frenet-Serret equations is that they allow to fully characterize space curves in terms of curvature and torsion. This is known as the *Fundamental Theorem of Space Curves* which can be informally stated as:

> If we prescribe two functions $\kappa(t)>0$ and $\tau(t)$, there exists a unit-speed curve $\g(t)$ which has curvature $\kappa(t)$ and torsion $\tau(t)$. Moreover $\gamma$ is the **only curve** with such curvature and torsion, up to rigid motions.


A rigid motion is a rotation about the origin,
followed by a translation. Therefore the Theorem is saying that there exists a unique $\g$ with curvature $\kappa$ and torsion $\tau$, up to rotations and translations.

Let us give the analytic definition of rigid motion.


::: Definition
### Rigid motion

A *rigid motion* of $\R^3$ is a map $M \colon \R^3 \to \R^3$ of the form
$$
M(\vv) = R \vv + \pp \,, \qquad \vv \in \R^3 \,,
$$
where $\pp \in \R^3$ is a vector and $R \in \R^{3 \times 3}$ is
a **rotation matrix**, i.e.,
$$
R \in \mathrm{SO}(3) := \{ R \in \R^{3 \times 3} \ \colon \ R^T R = I \,, \,\, \det(R) = 1 \} \,.
$$

:::

In the above definition $I$ is the identity matrix in $\R^3$
$$
I = 
\left(
\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{array}
\right)
$$
It is also useful to introduce the set of **orthogonal matrices**
$$
\mathrm{O}(3) := \{ A \in \R^{3 \times 3} \ \colon \ A^T A = I \}
$$
Notice that for $A \in \mathrm{O}(3)$ we have
$$
\det(A) = \pm 1
$$
Therefore rotations are orthogonal matrices with deteminant $1$.

> Proof. We have
$$
1 = \det(I) = \det (A^T A) =  \det (A) \det (A^T) = \det (A)^2
$$
and therefore $\det(A) = \pm 1$.




The precise statement of the *Fundamental Theorem of Space Curves* is as follows.



::: Theorem
### Fundamental Theorem of Space Curves  {#theorem-characterization-space}

Let $\kappa, \tau \ \colon (a,b) \to \R$ be smooth functions, with $\kappa>0$. Then:

1. There exists a unit-speed curve $\g \ \colon (a,b) \to \R^3$ with curvature $\kappa(t)$ and torsion $\tau(t)$.

2. Suppose that $\tg \ \colon (a,b) \to \R^3$ is a unit-speed curve whose curvature $\tkappa$ and torsion $\ttau$ satisfy
$$
\tkappa(t) = \kappa(t) \,, \quad 
\ttau(t) = \tau(t) 
  \,, \quad \forall \, t \in (a,b) \,.
$$
Then there exists a rigid motion $M \colon \R^3 \to \R^3$ such that
$$
\tg(t) = M (\g(t)) \,, \qquad \forall \, t \in (a,b) \,.
$$

:::

In other words, curvature and torsion fully characterize space curves. This result is the 3D counterpart of
Theorem \ref{theorem-characterization-plane}, which said that signed curvature characterizes 2D curves.



The proof of Theorem \ref{theorem-characterization-space} is rather lengthy and technical. We delay it to the end of the chapter, see Section (@sec-FTSC-proof).
For now, let us show a simple application of Theorem \ref{theorem-characterization-space}.


::: Example
### Application of Fundamental Theorem of Curves

In Example \ref{example-circle-rotated} we have considered the unit-speed curve
$$
\g(t) := \left( \frac45 \cos(t),  1 - \sin(t) , -\frac35 \cos(t)  \right) \,,
$$
for $t \in [0,2\pi]$. We have computed that 
$$
\kappa = 1 \,, \quad \tau = 0 \,. 
$$
If we plot $\g$, we clearly see that $\g$ is just obtained by translating and 
rotating a unit circle, see plot in @fig-circle-rigid. Theorem \ref{theorem-characterization-space} enables
us to rigorously prove this claim. Indeed, consider the unit-speed circle
$$
\tg(t) := \left( \cos(t), \sin(t) , 0  \right) \,,
$$
for $t \in [0,2\pi]$. In Example \ref{example-circle-curvature-torsion} we have proven that curvature and torsion are  
$$
\tkappa = 1 \,, \quad \ttau = 0 \,. 
$$
Therefore 
$$
\kappa = \tkappa\,, \quad \tau = \ttau  \,,
$$
and by Theorem  \ref{theorem-characterization-space} we conclude that there exist a rigid motion $M \colon \R^3 \to \R^3$ such that
$$
\g(t) = M(\tg(t))  \,, \quad \forall \,  t \in [0,2\pi] \,.
$$
:::




## Applications of Frenet-Serret


We now state and prove two results which directly follow from the Frenet-Serret equations. They state, respectively:

1. A curve has torsion $\tau = 0$ if and only if it is contained in a plane.

2. A curve has constant curvature $\kappa > 0$ and torsion $\tau = 0$ if and only if it is part of a circle.


Before proceeding, we recall the definition plane in $\R^3$.



::: Remark
### Equation of a plane

The general equation of a plane $\pmb{\pi}_d$ in $\R^3$ is given by

$$
\pmb{\pi}_d = \{ \xx \in \R^3 \, \colon \,  \xx \cdot \mathbf{P} = d \}\,,
$$
for some vector $\mathbf{P} \in \R^3$ and scalar $d \in \R$. Note that:

1. If $d = 0$, the condition
$$
\xx \cdot \mathbf{P} = 0
$$
is saying that the plane $\pmb{\pi}_0$ contains all the points $\xx$ in $\R^3$ which are orthogonal to $\mathbf{P}$. In particular $\pmb{\pi}_0$ contains the origin $\zero$. 

2. If $d \neq 0$, then $\pmb{\pi}_d$ is the translation of $\pmb{\pi}_0$ by the quantity $d$ in direction $\mathbf{P}$.

 In both cases, $\mathbf{P}$ is the normal vector to the plane, as shown in @fig-general-plane.
:::


![The plane $\pmb{\pi}_0$ is the set of points of $\R^3$ orthogonal to $\mathbf{P}$. The plane $\pmb{\pi}_d$ is obtained by translating $\pmb{\pi}_0$ by a quantity $d$ in direction $\mathbf{P}$.](/images/general_plane.png){#fig-general-plane width=70%}





::: {.Proposition  #proposition-zero-torsion}

Let $\g \colon (a,b) \to \R^3$ be regular and such that $\kappa \neq 0$. They are equivalent:


1. The torsion of $\g$ satisfies 
$$
\tau(t) = 0 \,, \quad \forall  \, t \in (a,b) \,.
$$

2. The image of $\g$ is contained in a plane, that is, there exists a vector $\mathbf{P} \in \R^3$ and a scalar $d \in \R$ such that
$$
\g(t)\cdot \mathbf{P} = d \,, \quad \forall t \in (a,b) \,.
$$


:::


**Idea of the proof:**
The third Frenet-Serret equation states that
$$
\dot{\bb} = - \tau \nn 
$$
Therefore $\tau=0$ if and only if $\dot{\bb} = 0$, which means
that $\bb$ is constant. Now, $\bb$ is orthogonal to the other 
two vectors $\ttt, \nn$ of the Frenet-Frame. Since $\bb$ is constant, this means $\ttt, \nn$ span a constant plane which has $\bb$ as normal vector. This tells us $\g$ is contained in the plane
$$
\g \cdot \bb = d 
$$
for suitable $d \in \R$. Let's prove this!
 

::: Proof

Without loss of generality we can assume that $\g$ is unit-speed. 

> Proof. If we were to consider $\tg$ a unit-speed reparametrization of $\g$, then $\tg$ would still be contained in the same plane as $\g$ is contained.
Moreover curvature and torsion are invariante under reparametrization, and so $\tg$ would still have non-zero curvature and identically zero torsion.


As $\g$ is unit-speed, it is well defined the Frenet frame
$$
\{ \ttt(t), \nn(t) ,\bb(t) \} \,.
$$


*Step 1.* Suppose $\tau = 0$ for all $t$. By the third Frenet-Serret equation
$$
\dot{\bb} = -\tau(t) \nn = \zero \,,
$$
so that $\bb(t)$ is constant. As by definition 
$$
\bb = \ttt \times \nn \,,
$$ 
we conclude that the vectors $\ttt(t)$ and $\nn(t)$ always span the same plane, which has constant normal vector $\bb$. Intuition suggests that $\g$ should be contained in such plane, see Figure @fig-proof-plane. Indeed
$$
\frac{d}{dt} ( \g \cdot \bb ) = \dg \cdot \bb + \ddg \cdot \dot{\bb} = 0\,,
$$
where we used that $\dot{\bb}=0$ and that the Frenet frame is orthonormal, i.e.
$$
\dg \cdot \bb = \ttt \cdot \bb = 0 \,.
$$
Thus $\g \cdot \bb$ has zero derivative, meaning it is constant: there exists $d \in \R$ such that
$$
\g(t) \cdot \bb = d \,, \,\, \forall \, t \in (a,b) \,.
$${#eq-plane-conclusion}
This shows that $\g$ is conatained in a plane orthogonal to $\bb$, and the first part of the proof is concluded.



*Step 2.* Suppose that $\g$ is contained in a plane. Hence there exists $\mathbf{P} \in \R^3$ and $d \in \R$ such that 
$$
\g(t)\cdot \mathbf{P} = d \,, \quad \forall \, t \in (a,b) \,.
$$
We can differentiate the above equation twice to obtain
$$
\dg \cdot \mathbf{P} = 0 \,, \quad   \ddg \cdot \mathbf{P} = 0 \,,
$$
where we used that $\mathbf{P}$ and $d$ are constant. The first equation says that
$\dg(t)$ is orthogonal to $\mathbf{P}$.
By the first Frenet-Serret equation we have
$$
\ddg (t)= \dot{\ttt} = \kappa (t) \nn (t) \,.
$$
Therefore the already proven relation $\ddg \cdot \mathbf{P} = 0$ implies
$$
\kappa (t) \nn (t) \cdot \mathbf{P} = 0 \,.
$$
As we are assuming $\kappa \neq 0$, we deduce that
$$
\nn (t) \cdot \mathbf{P} = 0 \,, \quad \forall \, t \in (a,b) \,.
$$
In conclusion, we have shown that $\mathbf{P}$ is orthogonal to both $\dg(t)$ and $\nn(t)$. Since $\bb(t)$ is orthogonal to both $\dg(t)$ and $\nn(t)$, we conclude that $\bb(t)$ is parallel to $\mathbf{P}$. Hence, there exists $\lambda(t) \in \R$ such that
$$
\bb(t) = \lambda(t) \mathbf{P} \,, \quad \forall \, t \in (a,b) \,.
$$
Since $\norm{\bb} = 1$ and $\mathbf{P}$ is constant, from (@eq-proof-plane) we conclude that $\lambda(t)$ is constant
and non-zero. Thus
$$
\bb(t) = \hat{\lambda} \mathbf{P} \,, \quad \forall \, t \in (a,b) \,,
$${#eq-proof-plane}
for some $\hat{\lambda} \neq 0$. Differentiating (@eq-proof-plane) we obtain
$$
\dot{\bb}(t) = 0 \,, \quad \forall \, t \in (a,b) \,,
$$
meaning that the binormal $\bb$ is a constant vector. By definition of torsion
$$
\tau(t) = - \dot{\bb} \cdot \nn(t) = 0 \,, \quad \forall \, t \in (a,b) \,,
$$
as required.
:::



![If $\bb$ is constant, then $\g$ lies in the plane spanned by $\dg$ and $\nn$. Note that $\bb$ is the unit normal to such plane.](/images/proof_plane_intuition.png){#fig-proof-plane width=70%}



As a corollary of Step 1 in the proof of Proposition \ref{proposition-zero-torsion}
we obtain the following statement.


::: {.Corollary  #corollary-zero-torsion}

Let $\g \colon (a,b) \to \R^3$ be regular and such that $\kappa \neq 0$. Suppose that
the torsion
$$
\tau(t) = 0 \,, \quad \forall \, t \in (a,b)\,.
$$
Then the binormal $\bb$ is a constant vector, and the image of $\g$ is contained in the plane of equation
$$
(\xx - \g(t_0)) \cdot \bb = 0 \,,
$$
where $t_0 \in (a,b)$ is arbitrarily chosen. Note that such plane is orthogonal to the binormal $\bb$.

:::


::: Proof

Following the proof of Step 1 of Proposition \ref{proposition-zero-torsion}, 
we get to the conclusion (@eq-plane-conclusion) that $\g$ satisfies
$$
\g(t) \cdot \bb = d \,, \,\, \forall \, t \in (a,b) \,.
$$
As the above equation holds for each $t$, we can fix an arbitrary $t_0 \in (a,b)$ and
find that the constant $d$ is
$$
d = \g(t_0) \cdot \bb 
$$
Hence we obtain
$$
(\g(t) - \g(t_0)) \cdot \bb = 0 \,, \,\, \forall \, t \in (a,b) \,.
$$
The above is says that $\g$ is contained in the plane (orthogonal to $\bb$) with equation
$$
(\xx - \g(t_0)) \cdot \bb = 0
$$

:::


::: Example 

Consider again the curve of Example \ref{example-circle-rotated}
$$
\g(t) := \left( \frac45 \cos(t),  1 - \sin(t) , -\frac35 \cos(t)  \right) \,,
$$
for $t \in \R$. Recall that $\g$ is a Circle which has been rotated an translated, as shown in @fig-circle-rigid. We have
already proven in Example \ref{example-circle-rotated} that the curvature and torsion satisfy
$$
\kappa = 1 \,, \qquad \tau = 0 \,.  
$$
Since $\kappa \neq 0$ and $\tau=0$, we can apply Corollary \ref{corollary-zero-torsion} and infer that $\g$ is contained in the plane of equation
$$
	(\xx - \g(t_0)) \cdot \bb = 0 \,, \quad \xx \in \R^3 \,,
$$
where $\bb$ is the binormal vector to $\g$. As computed in Example \ref{example-circle-rotated} we have
$$
\bb =  \left( -\frac35, 0, -\frac45 \right) \,.
$$
Next, we take a point on the curve. At $t = \pi/2$ we have
$$
\g(0) = \zero 
$$
The equation of the plane is then
$$
-\frac{3}{5} x -  \frac{4}{5} z = 0
$$
Simplifying, we obtain that $\g$ is contained in the plane of equation
$$
3x + 4z = 0 \, .
$$
:::






We now state and prove the second result anticipated at the beginning of this section.


::: {.Proposition #proposition-constant-k-zero-t}

Let $\g \colon (a,b) \to \R^3$ be a unit-speed curve. They are equivalent:


1. The image of $\g$ is contained in a circle of radius $1/c$.


2. The curvature and torsion of $\g$ satisfy
$$
\kappa (t) = c \,, \quad  \tau(t) = 0\,,  \quad \forall \, t \in (a,b)\,, 
$$
for some constant $c > 0$.


:::


Proposition \ref{proposition-constant-k-zero-t} is actually a consequence of the Fundamental Theorem of Space Curves Theorem 
\ref{theorem-characterization-space}, and of the fact that we have computed 
that for a circle of radius $R$ one has
$$
\kappa  = \frac1R \,, \quad  \tau = 0\,.
$$
Therefore, by Theorem \ref{theorem-characterization-space}, every unit-speed curve $\g$ with
constant curvature and torsion must be equal to a circle, up to rigid motions. 

Nevertheless, we still give a proof of Proposition \ref{proposition-constant-k-zero-t}, 
to show yet another explicit application of the Frenet-Serret equations.


::: Proof
*Step 1.* Suppose the image of $\g$ is contained in a circle of radius $1/c$. Then, up to a translation, $\g$ is parametrized by 
$$
\g(t) = \left( \frac{1}{c} \cos(t) ,   \frac{1}{c} \sin(t) , 0 \right) \,.
$$
We have already seen that in this case
$$
\kappa = c  \,, \quad \tau = 0 \,,
$$
concluding the proof.


*Step 2.* Suppose that 
$$
\kappa (t) = c \,, \quad  \tau(t) = 0\,,  \quad \forall \, t \in (a,b)\,, 
$$
for some constant $c \in \R$. Since $\g$ is unit-speed, it is well defined the 
Frenet frame 
$$
\{ \ttt, \nn ,\bb \} \,.
$$
Due to the assumptions on $\kappa$ and $\tau$ the Frenet-Serret equations read
\begin{align*}
\dot{\ttt} & = \kappa \nn = c \nn \\
\dot{\nn} & = - \kappa \ttt + \tau \bb = -c \ttt \\
\dot{\bb} & = -\tau \nn = \zero  
\end{align*}
In particular $\dot{\bb}=\zero$ and so $\bb$ is a constant vector. As seen in the proof Proposition \ref{proposition-zero-torsion}, this implies that $\g$ is contained in a plane $\p$ orthogonal to $\bb$, see @fig-proof-plane. As $c$ is constant we get
$$
\frac{d}{dt} \left(  \g  + \frac1c \nn   \right)  = \dg + \frac{1}{c} \dot{\nn} = \ttt - \frac1c 
\, c \ttt = 0 \,,
$$
where we used that $\dg = \ttt$ and the second Frenet-Serret equation. Therefore 
$$ 
\g(t)  + \frac1c \nn(t) = \pp \,, \quad  t \in (a,b) \,,
$$
for some constant point $\pp \in \R^3$. In particular
$$
\norm{ \g(t) - \pp } =   \norm{  -\frac1c \nn(t) } =  \frac{1}{|c|} = \frac1c \,,
$$
since $\nn$ is a unit vector and $c>0$. The above shows that $\g$ is contained in a sphere of radius $1/c$ and center $\pp$. In formulas:
$$
\g(t) \in \SSS := \{  \xx \in \R^3 \, \colon \,  \norm{\xx - \pp} = 1/c    \} \,.
$$
The intersection of $\SSS$ with the plane $\p$ is a circle $\mathcal{C}$ with some radius $R \geq 0$ (note that $\mathcal{C}$ might be a single point, in which case $R = 0$).
As we have shown 
$$
\g \in  \p \,, \quad \g \in \SSS \,,
$$
we conclude that
$$
\g \in   \p  \cap \SSS  = \mathcal{C} \,.
$${#eq-proof-contained-circle}
Therefore $\g$ parametrizes part of $\mathcal{C}$. This immediately implies that
$R > 0$.

> Proof. If $R = 0$ then $\mathcal{C}$ is a single point, meaning that $\g$ is constant. But then $\dg = 0$ which contradicts the assumption that $\g$ is unit speed.

Since $\mathcal{C}$ is a circle of radius $R>0$, Step 1 of the proof implies that the curvature and torsion of $\g$ satisfy
$$
\kappa = \frac1R \,, \quad \tau = 0 \,.
$$
As by assumption $\kappa=c$, we conclude that $R=1/c$. Therefore the circle $\mathcal{C}$ has radius $1/c$ and the thesis follows by (@eq-proof-contained-circle).

:::






## Proof: Curvature and torsion formulas

Another consequence of the Frenet-Serret equations is that they allow us to finally 
prove the curvature and torsion formulas given in Proposition \ref{proposition-curvature-formula} and Proposition \ref{proposition-torsion-formula}. For reader's convenience we recall these two results.


::: Proposition 
### Curvature and torsion formulas  {#proposition-curvature-torsion-formulas}

Let $\g \colon (a,b) \to \R^3$ be a regular curve. The curvature $\kappa(t)$ of $\g$ at $\g(t)$ is given by
$$
\kappa(t) = \frac{ \norm{\dg \times \ddg} }{ \norm{\dg}^3 } \,. 
$${#eq-curv-proof}
If $\kappa >0$ the torsion $\tau(t)$ of $\g$ at $\g(t)$ is given by
$$
\tau (t) = \frac{ ( \dg \times \ddg ) \cdot \dddg }{ \norm{ \dg \times \ddg }^2 } \,. 
$${#eq-torsion-proof}

:::



::: Proof

By assumption $\g$ is regular. Denote by $\tg = \g \circ s^{-1}$ the arc-length reparametrization. As $\tg$ is unit-speed, it is well defined its Frenet frame
$$
\left\{\tttt (s), \tnn (s), \tbb (s) \right\}  \,, \quad \tttt =\dtg 
$$
The Frenet-Serret equations are
\begin{align*}
\dot{\tttt} & = \tkappa \ \tnn \\
\dot{ \tnn } & = - \tkappa \ \tttt + \ttau \ \tbb \\
\dot{\tbb} & = - \ttau \ \tnn
\end{align*}
where $\tkappa$ and $\ttau$ are the curvature and torsion of $\tg$.



*Part 1.* Differentiating $\g = \tg \circ s$ we get
$$
\dg(t) = \dtg(s(t)) \ \dot{s}(t) = \tttt (s(t)) \ \dot{s}(t)
$$
Differentiating once more
$$
\begin{aligned}
\ddg (t) & = \frac{d}{dt} \left[ \tttt (s(t)) \ \dot{s}(t)   \right] \\
                    & =  \dot{\tttt} \dot{s}^2  +  \tttt \, \ddot{s}  \\
                    & =  \tkappa \ \tnn \ \dot{s}^2  +  \tttt \, \ddot{s}
\end{aligned}
$${#eq-prop-curvature-torsion-1}
where in the last line we used the first Frenet-Serret equation. We are also omitting the dependence on the point for brevity. We compute
$$
\begin{aligned}
\dg(t) \times \ddg (t) & =   \tttt \ \dot{s} \times  \left[  \tkappa \ \tnn \  \dot{s}^2  +  \tttt \ \ddot{s} \right] \\
& = \dot{s}^3 \ \tkappa \ \tttt \times \tnn +
\dot{s} \ \ddot{s} \ \tttt \times \tttt \\
& = \dot{s}^3 \ \tkappa \ \tbb
\end{aligned}
$${#eq-prop-curvature-torsion}
where we used that $\tbb = \tttt \times \tnn$ by definition, and that $\tttt \times \tttt = 0$ by the properties of the cross product. Taking the norms in (@eq-prop-curvature-torsion) gives
$$
\norm{ \dg(t) \times \ddg (t) } =   \norm{ \g(t) }^3 \ \tkappa(s(t)) 
$$
where we used that $\norm{\tbb} = 1$ and $\dot{s} (t) = \norm{ \g(t) }$.
Rearranging we get
$$
\tkappa(s(t)) = \frac{ \norm{ \dg(t) \times \ddg (t) } }{ \norm{ \g(t) }^3 }
$$
Recalling that the curvature $\kappa$ of $\g$ at $t$ is defined as
$$
\kappa(t) = \tkappa( s(t) )
$$
we conclude (@eq-curv-proof).


*Part 2*. Differentiating the second line in  (@eq-prop-curvature-torsion-1) we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
\dddot{\g}(t) & = \frac{d}{dt} \left[ \dot{\tttt}(s(t)) \dot{s}^2(t)  +  \tttt(s(t)) \, \ddot{s}(t) \right] \\
              & = \ddot{\tttt} \dot{s}^3 + 2\dot{\tttt} \dot{s} \ddot{s} + \dot{\tttt} \dot{s} \ddot{s} + \tttt \ \dddot{s} \\
              & = \ddot{\tttt} \dot{s}^3 + 3\dot{\tttt} \dot{s} \ddot{s} + \tttt \ \dddot{s} 
\end{aligned}
$$
Therefore, using (@eq-prop-curvature-torsion), we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
\left( \dg \times \ddg  \right) \cdot \dddot{\g} & = 
\left[\dot{s}^3 \tkappa \ \tbb \right] \cdot 
\left [ \ddot{\tttt} \dot{s}^3 + 3\dot{\tttt} \dot{s} \ddot{s} + \tttt \ \dddot{s} \right] \\
& = \dot{s}^6 \ \tkappa \  \tbb \cdot  \ddot{\tttt} +
3\dot{s}^4  \ \ddot{s} \ \tkappa \ \tbb \cdot \dot{\tttt}  +
\dot{s}^3 \ \dddot{s} \  \tkappa \ \tbb \cdot \tttt \\
& =  \dot{s}^6 \ \tkappa \  \tbb \cdot  \ddot{\tttt}
\end{aligned} 
$${#eq-prop-curvature-torsion-2}
where the second term is zero by the first Frenet-Serret equation
$$
\tbb \cdot \dot{\tttt} = \tkappa \ \tbb \cdot \tnn = 0 \,,
$$
as $\tbb \cdot \tnn = 0$, and the thrid term is zero because  $\tbb \cdot \tttt = 0$. To compute $\ddot{\tttt}$ we differentiate the first Frenet-Serret formula
$$
\begin{aligned}
\ddot{\tttt} & = \frac{d}{ds} \left[ \dot{\tttt}  \right] \\
             & = \frac{d}{ds} \left[ \tkappa  \ \tnn \right] \\
             & = \dot{\tkappa}  \ \tnn + \tkappa  \ \dot{\tnn}  
\end{aligned}
$$
Substituting in (@eq-prop-curvature-torsion-2) we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
\left( \dg \times \ddg  \right) \cdot \dddot{\g} 
& = \dot{s}^6 \ \tkappa \  \tbb \cdot  \ddot{\tttt} \\
& = \dot{s}^6 \ \tkappa \  \tbb \cdot \left[ \dot{\tkappa}  \ \tnn + \tkappa  \ \dot{\tnn}  \right] \\
& = \dot{s}^6 \ \tkappa \ \dot{\tkappa} \  \tbb \cdot \tnn +
\dot{s}^6 \ \tkappa^2 \ \tbb \cdot  \dot{\tnn} \\
& = \dot{s}^6 \ \tkappa^2 \ \tbb \cdot  \dot{\tnn}
\end{aligned}
$$
where we used that $\tbb \cdot \tnn = 0$. Using the second Frenet-Serret equation we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
\left( \dg \times \ddg  \right) \cdot \dddot{\g} 
& = \dot{s}^6 \ \tkappa^2 \ \tbb \cdot  \dot{\tnn} \\
& = \dot{s}^6 \ \tkappa^2 \ \tbb \cdot \left[  -\tkappa \ \tttt + \ttau \ \tbb  \right] \\
& = -  \dot{s}^6 \ \tkappa^3 \ \tbb \cdot \tttt + \dot{s}^6 \ \tkappa^2 \ \ttau \ \tbb \cdot \tbb \\
& = \dot{s}^6 \ \tkappa^2 \ \ttau
\end{aligned}
$$
where we used that $\tbb \cdot \tttt = 0$ and $\tbb \cdot \tbb = 1$. Recalling that $\dot s = \norm{\dg}$, and using the already proven formula (@eq-curv-proof), we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
\left( \dg \times \ddg  \right) \cdot \dddot{\g}  & = \dot{s}^6 \ \tkappa^2 \ \ttau \\
& = \norm{\tg}^6 \ \frac{ \norm{\dg \times \ddg}^2 }{ \norm{\dg}^6 }   \ \ttau \\
& = \norm{\dg \times \ddg}^2 \ \ttau
\end{aligned}
$$
Rerranging we get
$$
\ttau (s(t)) = \frac{ \left( \dg(t) \times \ddg(t)  \right) \cdot \dddot{\g}(t) }{ \norm{\dg(t) \times \ddg(t)}^2  }
$$
Recalling that the torsion $\tau$ of $\g$ at $t$ is defined as
$$
\tau(t) = \ttau ( s(t) )
$$
we conclude (@eq-torsion-proof).

:::





::: {.content-hidden}

Before proceeding with the proof, we need to establish some notation.

::: Notation
### Compact notation for derivatives


Let $\g \colon (a,b) \to \R^n$ be a regular curve and
$s \colon (a,b) \to (\tilde{a},\tilde{b})$ its arc-length
function. Denote by
$$
\tg := \g \circ s^{-1}
$$
the arc-length reparametrization of $\g$. 
In the previous Chapter we used the letters:

1. $s$ to denote the *arc-length parameter*
2. $t$ to denote an *arbitrary parameter*

With this choice the parameter of the arc-length function is $t$
$$
s = s(t)
$$
and the parameter of the inverse $\psi := s^{-1}$ of the arc-length is $s$
$$
\psi = \psi (s)
$$
We equivalently denote the inverse of $s$ by
$$
t = t(s)
$$
In particular the relations $\g = \tg \circ s$ and $\tg = \g \circ s^{-1}$ read
$$
\g (t) = \tg(s(t)) \,, \quad t \in (a,b)
$$
and also
$$
\tg (s) = \g(t(s)) \,, \quad s \in (\tilde{a},\tilde{b}) 
$$

We will denote:

1. The derivative of the arc-length function $s(t)$ by
$$
\dot s(t) = \frac{ds}{dt}(t)
$$

2. The derivative of the inverse of the arc-length function $t(s)$ by
$$
\dot t(s) = \frac{dt}{ds}(s)
$$

Moreover:

- The derivative of $\g(t)$ is denoted by 
$$
\dg(t) = \frac{d\g}{dt}(t)  \,, \quad  t \in (a,b)
$$

- The derivative of $\tg(s)$ is denoted by
$$
\dtg(s) = \frac{d\tg}{ds}(s)  \,, \quad  s \in (\tilde{a},\tilde{b}) \,.
$$


According to the above notations, this is how we can write the **chain rule**:

- The chain rule for $\g = \tg \circ s$ is the old notations is:
$$
\dg(t) = \dtg(s(t)) \, \dot{s} (t) \,, \quad t \in (a,b) \,.
$$
In the new notations the above chain rule is written
$$
\frac{d\g}{dt}(t) = \frac{d\tg}{ds}(s(t)) \, \frac{ds}{dt}(t) \,, \quad t \in (a,b) \,.
$$
We will often omit the dependence on the point $t$ by writing
$$
\frac{d\g}{dt} = \frac{d\tg}{ds} \, \frac{ds}{dt} 
$$

- The chain rule for $\tg = \g \circ s^{-1}$ in the old notation is:
$$
\dtg(s) = \dg( t(s) ) \, \dot{t}(s) \,, \quad 
s \in (\tilde{a},\tilde{b}) \,.
$$
In the new notations the above chain rule is written
$$
\frac{d\tg}{ds}(s) = \frac{d\g}{dt}( t(s) )  \, \frac{dt}{ds} ( s ) \,,\quad s \in (\ta,\tb) \,,
$$
Omitting the dependence on the point $s$, the above reads
$$
\frac{d\tg}{ds} = \frac{d\g}{dt} \, \frac{dt}{ds} 
$$
:::


::: Example 
### How to use the new notations

Let $\g$ be regular and $\tg := \g \circ s^{-1}$ an arc-length reparametrization fo $\g$. We already know that $\tg$ is unit-speed:
$$
\norm{\dtg(s)} = 1\,, \quad \forall \, s \in (\tilde{a}, \tilde{b})  \,.
$${#eq-new-notations-1}
As an exercise, let us prove (@eq-new-notations-1) using the new notations. By chain rule we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
\norm{\dtg(s)} & = \norm{ \frac{d\tg}{ds} (s) } \\
               & = \norm{\frac{d\g}{dt} (t(s))} \, \left| \frac{dt}{ds}(s) \right|
\end{aligned}
$${#eq-new-notations-2bis}
Now, recall that 
$$
\frac{ds}{dt}(t) = \dot{s}(t) = \norm{\dg (t)}
= \norm{ \frac{d\g}{dt} (t) }
$${#eq-new-notations-2}
As $t$ is the inverse of $s$, by the inverse function theorem we get
$$
\frac{dt}{ds}(s) = \frac{1}{\left(\dfrac{ds}{dt} (t(s)) \right)} = \frac{ 1 }{ \norm{ \dfrac{d\g}{dt} (t(s)) } }
$$
where we used (@eq-new-notations-2) evaluated at $t(s)$. From (@eq-new-notations-2bis)
\begin{align*}
\norm{\dtg(s)} & = \norm{\frac{d\g}{dt} (t(s))} \, \left| \frac{dt}{ds}(s) \right| \\
              & = \norm{\frac{d\g}{dt} (t(s))}  \frac{1}{\norm{\dfrac{d\g}{dt} (t(s))} } = 1
\end{align*}
concluding (@eq-new-notations-1).
:::


We will heavily rely on the new notations for proving Proposition \ref{proposition-curvature-torsion-formulas}.


:::




## Proof: Fundamental Theorem of Space Curves {#sec-FTSC-proof}


In this section we prove the *Fundamental Theorem of Space Curves* Theorem \ref{theorem-characterization-space}. For reader's convenience we recall the statement.



::: Theorem
### Fundamental Theorem of Space Curves  {#theorem-FTSC}

Let $\kappa, \tau \ \colon (a,b) \to \R$ be smooth functions, with $\kappa>0$. Then:

1. There exists a unit-speed curve $\g \ \colon (a,b) \to \R^3$ with curvature $\kappa(t)$ and torsion $\tau(t)$.

2. Suppose that $\tg \ \colon (a,b) \to \R^3$ is a unit-speed curve whose curvature $\tkappa$ and torsion $\ttau$ satisfy
$$
\tkappa(t) = \kappa(t) \,, \quad 
\ttau(t) = \tau(t) 
  \,, \quad \forall \, t \in (a,b) \,.
$$
Then there exists a rigid motion $M \colon \R^3 \to \R^3$ such that
$$
\tg(t) = M (\g(t)) \,, \qquad \forall \, t \in (a,b) \,.
$$

:::


The proof relies on the following classical existence Theorem for linear systems of ODEs. For a proof see Page 162 in [@walter].


::: Theorem
### Existence and uniqueness for linear ODE systems

Assume given a point $t_0 \in (a,b)$, a vector $\uu_0 \in \R^n$ and two functions
$$
A \colon (a,b) \to \R^{n \times n} \,, \qquad 
f \colon (a,b) \to \R^n
$$
of class $C^k$. There exists a unique function
$$
\uu \colon (a,b) \to \R^n
$$
of class $C^{k+1}$ which solves the Cauchy problem
$$
\begin{cases}
\dot{\uu} = A \uu + f \\
\uu (t_0) = \uu_0
\end{cases}
$$

:::


We will also need the following 4 Propositions. The first Proposition states
that orthogonal matrices preserve scalar product and length.


::: Proposition
### Orthogonal matrices preserve scalar product and length

Let $A \in \mathrm{O}(3)$ and $\vv,\ww \in \R^3$. Then
$$
A \vv \cdot A \ww = \vv \cdot \ww 
$${#eq-orthogonal-dot}
and also
$$
\norm{A \vv} = \| \vv \| 
$${#eq-orthogonal-length}

:::

::: Proof

For $\vv, \ww \in \R^3$
$$
A \vv \cdot A \ww = A^T A \vv \cdot \ww = \vv \cdot \ww
$$
where we used the properties of scalar product and that $A^T A = I$. 
In particular the above implies
$$
\norm{A \vv} = \sqrt{ A \vv \cdot A \vv} = \sqrt{ \vv \cdot  \vv}  = \| \vv \|
$$
concluding the proof.


:::


We now inverstigate how the cross product behaves under linear transformations, i.e.,
how the cross product of two vector changes under matrix multiplication.


::: Proposition
### Linear transformations of cross product

Let $A \in \R^{3 \times 3}$ be invertible and $\vv,\ww \in \R^3$. Then
$$
A \vv \times A \ww = \det(A) \left(A^{-1}\right)^{T} \left( \vv \times \ww \right) 
$${#eq-matrix-cross}
In particular for $R \in \mathrm{SO}(3)$ we have
$$
R \vv \times R \ww = R \left( \vv \times \ww \right)
$${#eq-rotation-cross}

:::

::: Proof

*Part 1.* Recall that the inverse of a matrix $A$ is computed by
$$
A^{-1} = \frac{1}{\det A}(\operatorname{cof} A)^{T}
$$
where $\operatorname{cof} M$ is the matrix of cofactors. 
By linearity of the cross product we only need to verify (@eq-matrix-cross)
on the vectors of the orthonormal basis $\ee_1,\ee_2,\ee_3$.
Let us verify (@eq-matrix-cross) for $\vv = \ee_1$ and $\ww = \ee_2$. Writing
$A\ee_1$ and $A\ee_2$ in coordinates
$$
A \ee_1 = \sum_{i=1}^3 m_{i 1}  \ee_i \,, \quad 
A \ee_2 = \sum_{i=1}^3 m_{i 2}  \ee_i
$$
for some coefficients $m_{i 1}, m_{i 2} \in \R$. By the formula for computing the vector product
(@eq-formula-cross-product) and definition of cofactor matrix
$$
\begin{aligned}
A \ee_1 \times A \ee_2 & = 
\sum_{i=1}^3 m_{i 1} \ee_i \times \sum_{j=1}^3 m_{j 2} \ee_{j} \\
& =\sum_{i<j} 
\left|\begin{array}{ll}
m_{i 1} & m_{i 2} \\
m_{j 1} & m_{j 2}
\end{array} \right| \ee_i \times \ee_j \\
& = \sum_{i=1}^3 (\operatorname{cof} \boldsymbol{A})_{i 3} \ee_i  \\
& = (\operatorname{cof} \boldsymbol{A}) \ee_3 \\
& =(\operatorname{det} A)\left(A^{-1}\right)^{T} \ee_3 \\
& =(\operatorname{det} A)\left(A^{-1}\right)^{T}\left(\ee_1 \times \ee_2\right)
\end{aligned}
$$
Calculations for the other cases are similar.

*Part 2.* For $R \in \mathrm{SO}(3)$ it holds $\det (R) = 1$. Moreover
$R^T R = I$, so that 
$$
R^{-1}= R^T \quad \implies \quad 
\left(R^{-1}\right)^{T} = R
$$
Therefore (@eq-rotation-cross) follows from (@eq-matrix-cross).

:::


We need to clarify how unit-speed curves and Frenet frame behave
under rigid motions.


::: Proposition
### Frenet Frame under rigid motions

Let $\g \colon (a,b) \to \R^3$ be unit-speed and $M \colon \R^3 \to \R^3$ be a rigid motion, i.e. such that 
$$
M(\vv) = R \, \vv + \pp 
$$
for some $R \in \mathrm{SO}(3)$ and $\pp \in \R^3$. Define the curve 
$$
\tg \colon (a,b) \to \R^3 \,, \qquad 
\tg(t) = M(\g(t)) \,.
$$
Then $\tg$ is unit-speed. Moreover the Frenet frame of $\tg$ is obtained by 
rotating the Frenet frame of $\g$ by $R$
$$
\tttt = R \, \ttt \,, \qquad
\tnn = R \, \nn  \,, \qquad 
\tbb = R \, \bb \,, \qquad
$${#eq-rigid-motion-frenet}

:::


::: Proof

Differentiating $\tg = M(\g) = R \, \g + \pp$ gives
$$
\dtg(t) = R \ \dg(t) \,, \qquad 
\ddtg(t) = R \ \ddg(t)
$$
Taking the norms in $\dtg = R \dg$ gives
$$
\norm{\dtg} = \norm{ R \dg } = \norm{\dg} = 1
$$
where we used that rotations preseve norms, see (@eq-orthogonal-length),
and the assumption of $\g$ unit-speed. This concludes the proof that $\tg$ is unit-speed.

Let us now prove (@eq-rigid-motion-frenet). The relation $\dtg = R \ \dg$ reads
$$
\tttt = R \, \ttt \,,
$$
which gives the first equation in (@eq-rigid-motion-frenet).
Since $\ddtg = R \ \ddg$, by (@eq-orthogonal-length) we deduce
$$
\norm{ \ddtg } = \norm{ R \ \ddg } = \norm{ \ddg }
$$
Therefore, by definition of principal normal,
$$
\tnn = \frac{ \ddtg }{ \norm{\ddtg} } = 
\frac{R \ \ddg}{\norm{ \ddg }} = R \, \nn \,,
$$
obtaining the second equation in (@eq-rigid-motion-frenet). Finally,
by definition of binormal and the first two equations in (@eq-rigid-motion-frenet),
$$
\tbb = \tttt \times \tnn
            = R \ \ttt \times R \ \nn
            = R \, (\ttt \times \nn)
            = R \, \bb
$$
where in the third equality we used (@eq-rotation-cross). The proof is concluded.

:::

For the last Proposition, consider a $3 \times 3$ time-dependent matrix
$$
A \colon (a,b) \to \R^{3 \times 3}
$$
With this matrix, define the $9 \times 9$ block matrix
$$
\mathbf{A} \colon (a,b) \to \R^{9 \times 9} \,, \quad 
\mathbf{A} = \left(
\begin{array}{ccc}
a_{11}I & a_{12}I & a_{13}I \\
a_{21}I & a_{22}I & a_{23}I \\
a_{31}I & a_{32}I & a_{33}I
\end{array} \right)
$${#eq-mathbf-A}
with $I$ the $3 \times 3$ identity matrix and $a_{ij}$ entries of $A$. 
Consider smooth functions $\uu_1, \uu_2, \uu_3 \colon (a,b) \to \R^3$ and with them define the $9$ dimensional vector
$$
\mathbf{u} \colon (a,b) \to \R^9 \,, \quad \mathbf{u}:= (\uu_1,\uu_2,\uu_3)
$${#eq-mathbf-u}



::: Proposition
### Evolution of orthonormal systems of vectors 

Let $A \colon (a,b) \to \R^{3 \times 3}$ be smooth and anti-symmetric, that is,
$$
A^T(t) = - A(t) \,, \quad  \forall \, t \in (a,b) \,.
$$
Let $\uu_1, \uu_2, \uu_3 \colon (a,b) \to \R^3$ be smooth functions satisfying the following ODE
$$
\left(
\begin{array}{c}
\dot{\uu}_1 \\
\dot{\uu}_2 \\
\dot{\uu}_3 
\end{array}
\right)
= A \ \left(
\begin{array}{c}
\uu_1 \\
\uu_2 \\
\uu_3 
\end{array}
\right)
$$
Suppose that for some $t_0 \in (a,b)$ the vectors 
$$
\uu_1(t_0) \,, \quad \uu_2(t_0) \,, \quad \uu_3(t_0)\,,
$$
are orthonormal. Then the vectors 
$$
\uu_1(t) \,, \quad \uu_2(t) \,, \quad \uu_3(t)\,,
$$
are orthonormal for all values of $t \in (a,b)$.

:::

::: Proof

For each pair $i,j$ define
$$
\lambda_{ij} := \uu_i \cdot \uu_j
$$
Further, define
$$
\delta_{ij} = 
\begin{cases}
1 & \text{if } \, i = j \\
0 & \text{if } \, i \neq j \\
\end{cases}
$$
Note that $\uu_1, \uu_2, \uu_3$ are orthonormal for all $t$ if and only if
$$
\lambda_{ij} = \delta_{ij} = 
\begin{cases}
1 & \text{if } \, i = j \\
0 & \text{if } \, i \neq j \\
\end{cases}
$${#eq-orthonormal-thesis}


$$
\dot{\uu}_i = \sum_{j=1}^3 a_{ij} \uu_j \,, \qquad \forall \, i =1,2,3\,.
$$
:::



We are finally ready to prove the Fundamental Theorem of Curves.


::: Proof
### Proof of Theorem \ref{theorem-FTSC}

*Part 1. Existence of $\g$*.

Let 
$$
(\ttt_0, \nn_0, \bb_0)
$$ 
be an orthonormal basis of $\R^3$ with positive orientation. By the properties of vector product we immediately conclude that 
$$
\bb_0 = \ttt_0 \times \nn_0
$$

> Proof. By assumption $\bb_0$ is a unit vector orthogonal to both 
$\ttt_0$ and $\nn_0$. Since $\ttt_0$ and $\nn_0$ are unit vectors,
by the properties of vector product we know that also 
$\ttt_0 \times \nn_0$ is a unit vector orthogonal to $\ttt_0$ and $\nn_0$.
Therefore
$$
\bb_0 = \lambda \ttt_0 \times \nn_0  \,, \qquad  \lambda = \pm 1
$$
and we get
$$
\det (\ttt_0 | \nn_0 | \bb_0) = \lambda \det(\ttt_0 | \nn_0 | \ttt_0 \times \nn_0 ) = \lambda \,,
$$
where in the second equality we used that 
$$
(\ttt_0, \nn_0, \ttt_0 \times \nn_0 )
$$ 
is an orthonormal basis of $\R^3$ with positive orientation, due to the properties of vector product. Hence $(\ttt_0, \nn_0, \bb_0)$ has positive orientation if and only if $\lambda = 1$ from which we get
$$ 
\bb_0 = \ttt_0 \times \nn_0
$$



*Part 2. Uniqueness up to rigid motions.*
